COMMAND.name: show ip bgp

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command displays BGP information including routes, neighbors, peer-group etc.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to display BGP neighbors, routes, peer-group etc. There are various CLI options available to display various informations from BGP. User can use "vrf" option to display information from a particular VRF instance of BGP. User can also choose ipv4 or ipv6 to display information from either of the address family. - show ip bgp summary This command will display BGP global parameters as well as brief information about BGP neighbors - show ip bgp This command will show BGP local RIB routes. User can use filtering options on CLI to zoom into a subset of routes that user is interested in - show ip bgp neighbor This will display one or all BGP neighbors information in detail - show ip bgp peer-group This will display one or all BGP peer-group information in detail

EXAMPLE.summary: Below are some of the sample outputs of show ip bgp command

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE:
leaf4# show ip bgp summary BGP router identifier 200.9.0.5, local AS number 100 Neighbor V AS MsgRcvd MsgSent InQ OutQ Up/Down State/PfxRcd 14.14.14.1 4 400 8 2 0 0 00:00:43 0
leaf4# show ip bgp BGP routing table information for VRF default Router identifier 200.9.0.5, local AS number 100 Route status codes: * - valid, > - best Origin codes: i - IGP, e - EGP, ? - incomplete Network Next Hop Metric LocPref Path *> 4.4.4.44/32 14.14.14.1 0 400 ? *> 10.59.128.0/20 14.14.14.1 0 400 ? *> 13.1.1.0/24 14.14.14.1 0 400 ? *> 14.14.14.0/24 14.14.14.1 0 400 ? *> 29.2.2.2/32 14.14.14.1 0 400 ? *> 192.168.1.0/24 14.14.14.1 0 400 ? *> 200.0.0.0/24 14.14.14.1 0 400 ?
leaf4# show ip bgp neighbors
BGP neighbor is 14.14.14.1, remote AS 400, local AS 100, external link Administratively shut down BGP version 4, remote router ID , local router ID BGP state = ESTABLISHED, up for 00:01:03 Hold time is seconds, keepalive interval is 60 seconds, negotiated hold time is 180 seconds Minimum time between advertisement runs is seconds Neighbor capabilities: 4 Byte AS: advertised and received Message statistics: InQ depth is 0 OutQ depth is 0 Sent Rcvd Opens: 1 1 Notifications: 0 0 Updates: 2 8 Keepalive: 2 2 Route Refresh: 0 0 Capability: 0 0 Total: 5 11
Local host: 14.14.14.4, Local port: 46782 Foreign host: 14.14.14.1, Foreign port: 179

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command clears/resets BGP information including neighbors, peer-group etc.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to clear BGP information. Following is a partial list of information with command syntax that can be cleared. - clear ip bgp * This command clears all BGP neighbors - clear ip bgp {ipv4 | ipv6} unicast * This command clears all BGP neighbors with this address-family and sub-address-family activated - clear ip bgp {ipv4 | ipv6} peer_ip * Clear peers with address of peer_ip and this address-family activated. - clear ip bgp {ipv6 | ipv4} soft {in | out} 'in" option will send route-refresh request unless using 'soft-reconfiguration inbound. 'out' option will resend all outbound updates

EXAMPLE.summary: Below command resets a BGP neighbor 14.14.14.1

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: leaf4# clear ip bgp 14.14.14.1

PARAM.name: vrf-name
PARAM.help: Name of VRF (Max size 15, prefixed by Vrf)

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command creates an instnace of BGP routing protocol in a VRF.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this config to create BGP routing instance in a VRF. If vrf key is not supplied by user, default-vrf is assumed. Only one instance of BGP protocol can be created in a VRF. Attempt to create more than one instance will result in command execution failure. If a BGP instance already exists, executing this command with same AS number will simply enter into the "router bgp ..." conifguration mode of the CLI.

EXAMPLE.summary: Below command creates a new BGP instance in default VRF with local AS number as 65300

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 65300

COMMAND.name: no router
COMMAND.ACTION:
for aft in IPV4_UNICAST IPV6_UNICAST ; do for proto in connected static ospf ; do
if test "$aft" = "IPV6_UNICAST" -a "$proto" = "ospf" ; then
python $SONIC_CLI_ROOT/sonic_cli_bgp.py delete_openconfig_network_instance_network_instances_network_instance_table_connections_table_connection ${vrf-name} $aft ospf3
fi
python $SONIC_CLI_ROOT/sonic_cli_bgp.py delete_openconfig_network_instance_network_instances_network_instance_table_connections_table_connection ${vrf-name} $aft $proto
done ; done
python $SONIC_CLI_ROOT/sonic_cli_bgp.py delete_openconfig_network_instance_network_instances_network_instance_protocols_protocol_bgp_global_config ${vrf-name}

VIEW.name: configure-router-bgp-view

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command configures router ID for an instance of BGP protocol
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to configure router ID for an instance of BGP protocol. Router ID configuration is optional for user. BGP automatically picks up one of the interface IP address as router ID if not configured explicitly by user.

EXAMPLE.summary: Below command configures router ID for BGP instance on default-VRF

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 65300 sonic(config-router-bgp)# router-id 163.134.6.97

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command enables Graceful Restart for an instance of BGP
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to enable BGP Graceful Restart globally in an instance of BGP. Changing the Graceful restart parameter will talke effect only on the fly will not take effect immediately. It will require all the BGP neighbors to be reset to take effect. This is because Graceful Restart capability must be negotiated with neighbors to make this feature functional.

EXAMPLE.summary: Below command enables Graceful Restart for BGP instance on default-VRF

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 65300 sonic(config-router-bgp)# graceful-restart enable

COMMAND.name: graceful-restart preserve-fw-state
COMMAND.help: Enable BGP graceful restart preserve FW state

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command instructs BGP to preserve forwarding state during Graceful Restart for an instance of BGP
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to enable BGP to preserve forwarding state of BGP during Graceful Restart.

EXAMPLE.summary: Below command enables preservation of forwarding state during Graceful Restart for BGP instance on default-VRF

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 65300 sonic(config-router-bgp)# graceful-restart preserve-fw-state

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command configures restart timer interval for BGP
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to configure BGP restart timer interval in seconds. This is optional parameter and determines how long peer routers will wait to delete stale routes before a BGP open message is received. The default value is 120 seconds.

EXAMPLE.summary: Below command configures restart timer interval to 180 seconds for BGP instance on default-VRF

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 65300 sonic(config-router-bgp)# graceful-restart restart-time 180

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command configures stale path timer interval for BGP
DOCGEN.USAGE: This command is used to set the maximum time to hold on to the stale paths of a gracefully restarted peer. All stale paths are deleted after the expiration of this timer. This is an optional parameter. The default is 360 seconds

EXAMPLE.summary: Below command configures stale path timer interval to 300 seconds for BGP instance on default-VRF

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 65300 sonic(config-router-bgp)# graceful-restart stalepath-time 300

COMMAND.name: always-compare-med
COMMAND.help: Allow comparing MED from different neighbors

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: Always compare the MED on routes, even when they were received from different neighbouring ASes. Setting this option makes the order of preference of routes more defined, and should eliminate MED induced oscillations.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to instruct BGP to always compare MED values for routes even if they are from different ASes

EXAMPLE.summary: Below command enables always-compare-med parameter

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 65300 sonic(config-router-bgp)# always-compare-med

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command configures subgroup coalesce timer interval in millseconds
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to configure subgroup coalesce timer interval

EXAMPLE.summary: Below command configures the coalesce timer interval to 2000 msec

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 65300 sonic(config-router-bgp)# coalesce-time 2000

COMMAND.name: read-quanta
COMMAND.help: How many packets to read from peer socket per I/O cycle

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command configures the maximum number of BGP packets to read from peer socker in one cycle of I/O
DOCGEN.USAGE: BGP packets are read off the wire one at a time in a loop. This setting controls how many iterations the loop runs for. It is best to leave this setting on the default.

EXAMPLE.summary: Below command configures the read-quanta to 6 packets

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 65300 sonic(config-router-bgp)# read-quanta 6

COMMAND.name: write-quanta
COMMAND.help: How many packets to write to peer socket per run

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command configures the maximum number of BGP packets to write to peer socker in one cycle of I/O
DOCGEN.USAGE: BGP message Tx I/O is vectored. This means that multiple packets are written to the peer socket at the same time each I/O cycle, in order to minimize system call overhead. This value controls how many are written at a time. Under certain load conditions, reducing this value could make peer traffic less bursty. In practice, leave this settings on the default (64).

EXAMPLE.summary: Below command configures the write-quanta to 50 packets

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 65300 sonic(config-router-bgp)# write-quanta 50

COMMAND.name: deterministic-med
COMMAND.help: Pick the best-MED path among paths advertised from the neighboring AS

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command enables to carry out route-selection in a way that produces deterministic results locally, even in the face of MED and the lack of a well-defined order of preference it can induce on routes.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Carry out route-selection in a way that produces deterministic answers locally, even in the face of MED and the lack of a well-defined order of preference it can induce on routes. Without this option the preferred route with MED may be determined largely by the order that routes were received in. Setting this option will have a performance cost that may be noticeable when there are many routes for each destination. Currently in BGP it is implemented in a way that scales poorly as the number of routes per destination increases. By default deterministic-med is disabled

EXAMPLE.summary: Below command enables deterministics-med

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 65300 sonic(config-router-bgp)# deterministic-med

COMMAND.name: disable-ebgp-connected-route-check

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command disables eBGP connected route check
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to disable checking if next-hop is conencted on ebgp sessions. When BGP peering is between the loopback interfaces, user should enable this option.

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 65300 sonic(config-router-bgp)# disable-ebgp-connected-route-check

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command enables Graceful shutdown feature
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to gracefully remove a BGP router from service. This command will instruct BGP to enter into graceful shutdown mode by resending routes with GSHUT community to all it's neighbors. This will enable all it's neighbor to route traffic around it so that router can be taken out of service without impact data forwarding

EXAMPLE.summary: Below command disables eBGP connected route check

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 65300 sonic(config-router-bgp)# graceful-shutdown

COMMAND.name: update-delay
COMMAND.help: Force initial delay for best-path and updates

VIEW.COMMAND:
<<<<<<< HEAD
||||||| merged common ancestors
=======
>>>>>>> broadcom_sonic_share
if test -z "${maxmedval}" ; then
python $SONIC_CLI_ROOT/sonic_cli_bgp.py delete_openconfig_bgp_ext_network_instances_network_instance_protocols_protocol_bgp_global_update_delay_config_establish_wait ${vrf-name}
fi
python $SONIC_CLI_ROOT/sonic_cli_bgp.py patch_openconfig_bgp_ext_network_instances_network_instance_protocols_protocol_bgp_global_update_delay_config ${vrf-name} ${time} ${maxmedval}
This command allows user to set update delay. This parameter control how long to wait before running best-path selection after Graceful Restart.
This feature is used to enable read-only mode on BGP process restart or when BGP process is cleared using clear ip bgp *. When applicable, read-only mode would begin as soon as the first peer reaches Established status and a timer for max-delay seconds is started. During this mode BGP doesn't run any best-path or generate any updates to its peers. This mode continues until: All the configured peers, except the shutdown peers, have sent explicit EOR (End-Of-RIB) or an implicit-EOR. The first keep-alive after BGP has reached Established is considered an implicit-EOR. If the establish-wait optional value is given, then BGP will wait for peers to reach established from the beginning of the update-delay till the establish-wait period is over, i.e. the minimum set of established peers for which EOR is expected would be peers established during the establish-wait window, not necessarily all the configured neighbors. max-delay period is over. On hitting any of the above two conditions, BGP resumes the decision process and generates updates to its peers. Default max-delay is 0, i.e. the feature is off by default.
sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 65300 sonic(config-router-bgp)# update-delay 120

COMMAND.name: bestpath as-path multipath-relax
COMMAND.help: Include prefixes received from different AS path during multipath calculation

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command specifies that BGP decision process should consider paths of equal AS_PATH length candidates for multipath computation. Without the knob, the entire AS_PATH must match for multipath computation.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to ignore as-path check for paths for the same prefix thereby making all the paths equal irrespctive of their as-path

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 65300 sonic(config-router-bgp)# bestpath as-path multipath-relax

PARAM.name: missing-as-worst

COMMAND.name: bestpath compare-routerid
COMMAND.help: Compare router-id for identical EBGP paths

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION:
This command influences best-path selection algorithm by comparing router-ids for identical eBGP routes Ensure that when comparing routes where both are equal on most metrics, including local-pref, AS_PATH length, IGP cost, MED, that the tie is broken based on router-ID.
If this option is enabled, then the already-selected check, where already selected eBGP routes are preferred, is skipped.
If a route has an ORIGINATOR_ID attribute because it has been reflected, that ORIGINATOR_ID will be used. Otherwise, the router-ID of the peer the route was received from will be used.
The advantage of this is that the route-selection (at this point) will be more deterministic. The disadvantage is that a few or even one lowest-ID router may attract all traffic to otherwise-equal paths because of this check. It may increase the possibility of MED or IGP oscillation, unless other measures were taken to avoid these. The exact behaviour will be sensitive to the iBGP and reflection topology.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to compare router-ids as tie-breaker for identical eBGP paths

EXAMPLE.summary: Below command instructs BGP to compare router-ids for identical eBGP paths

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 65300 sonic(config-router-bgp)# bestpath compare-routerid

COMMAND.name: disable-connected-check
COMMAND.help: One-hop away EBGP peer using loopback address

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command disables the restriction that eBGP peers must be directly connected
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to allow peerings between directly connected eBGP peers using loopback addresses.

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# neighbor 30.30.30.3 sonic(config-router-bgp-neighbor)# disable-connected-check

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION:
This command suppresses sending Capability Negotiation as OPEN message optional parameter to the peer. This command only affects the peer is configured other than IPv4 unicast configuration.
When remote peer does not have capability negotiation feature, remote peer will not send any capabilities at all. In that case, bgp configures the peer with configured capabilities.
You may prefer locally configured capabilities more than the negotiated capabilities even though remote peer sends capabilities. If the peer is configured by override-capability, BGP ignores received capabilities then override negotiated capabilities with configured values.
Additionally the user should be reminded that this feature fundamentally disables the ability to use widely deployed BGP features - BGP unnumbered, hostname support, AS4, Addpath, Route Refresh, ORF, Dynamic Capabilities, and graceful restart.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to disable capability negotiation for a BGP neighbor

EXAMPLE.summary: Following command disables capability negotiation for BGP neighbor 30.30.30.3

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# neighbor 30.30.30.3 sonic(config-router-bgp-neighbor)# dont-capability-negotiate

PARAM.name: no-prepend
PARAM.help: Do not prepend local-as to updates from ebgp peers

PARAM.name: replace-as
PARAM.help: Do not prepend local-as to updates from ibgp peers

COMMAND.ACTION:
if test -n "${no-prepend}" ; then
python $SONIC_CLI_ROOT/sonic_cli_bgp.py patch_openconfig_bgp_ext_network_instances_network_instance_protocols_protocol_bgp_neighbors_neighbor_config_local_as_no_prepend ${vrf-name} ${nbr-addr} True
else
python $SONIC_CLI_ROOT/sonic_cli_bgp.py patch_openconfig_bgp_ext_network_instances_network_instance_protocols_protocol_bgp_neighbors_neighbor_config_local_as_no_prepend ${vrf-name} ${nbr-addr} False
fi
if test -n "${replace-as}" ; then
python $SONIC_CLI_ROOT/sonic_cli_bgp.py patch_openconfig_bgp_ext_network_instances_network_instance_protocols_protocol_bgp_neighbors_neighbor_config_local_as_replace_as ${vrf-name} ${nbr-addr} True
else
python $SONIC_CLI_ROOT/sonic_cli_bgp.py patch_openconfig_bgp_ext_network_instances_network_instance_protocols_protocol_bgp_neighbors_neighbor_config_local_as_replace_as ${vrf-name} ${nbr-addr} False
fi
python $SONIC_CLI_ROOT/sonic_cli_bgp.py patch_openconfig_network_instance_network_instances_network_instance_protocols_protocol_bgp_neighbors_neighbor_config_local_as ${vrf-name} ${nbr-addr} ${asnum}

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION:
This command specifies an alternate AS for this BGP process when interacting with the specified peer. With no modifiers, the specified local-as is prepended to the received AS_PATH when receiving routing updates from the peer, and prepended to the outgoing AS_PATH (after the process local AS) when transmitting local routes to the peer.
If the no-prepend CLI option is specified, then the supplied local-as is not prepended to the received AS_PATH.
If the replace-as CLI option is specified, then only the supplied local-as is prepended to the AS_PATH when transmitting local-route updates to this peer.
Note that replace-as can only be specified if no-prepend is.
This command is only allowed for eBGP peers.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to configure local AS number for a BGP neighbor and control how the local AS number is prepended to the AS_PATH of incoming and outgoing routes.

EXAMPLE.summary: Following command configures local as and enables no-prepend for BGP neighbor 30.30.30.3

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# neighbor 30.30.30.3 sonic(config-router-bgp-neighbor)# local-as 65200 no-prepend

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command instructs BGP to override the result of Capability Negotiation with local configuration. Ignore remote peer's capability value.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to ignored the negotiated capability parameters with neighbor and instead use the locally configured parameters.

EXAMPLE.summary: Following command instructs BGP to ignore the negotiated parameters and use the locally configured one for BGP neighbor 30.30.30.3

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# neighbor 30.30.30.3 sonic(config-router-bgp-neighbor)# override-capability

COMMAND.help: Don't send open messages to this neighbor

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command makes BGP neighbor passive. That is, this BGP neighbor will not initiate a session. However, it will listen to any incoming BGP session.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to set a BGP neighbor as passive.

PARAM.name: encrypted
PARAM.help: The password is stored in an encrypted format

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command sets a MD5 password to be used with the tcp socket that is being used to connect to the remote peer.
DOCGEN.USAGE: This command is for security purposes. When Password is configures for a BGP neighbor, sender will include a 16-bytes MD5 digest in TCP header of BGP message and the receiver should be able to validate the digest then only accept the BGP message.

COMMAND.help: Solo peer - part of its own update group

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command is used to indicate that routes advertised by the peer should not be reflected back to the peer. This command is only meaningful when there is a single peer defined in the peer-group.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to set a neighbor solo

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command instructs BGP to strictly compare remote capabilities and local capabilities. If capabilities are different, send Unsupported Capability error then reset connection.

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# peer-group PG_Ext sonic(config-router-bgp-pg)# ebgp-multihop 10

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command configure the remote-as number for a BGP peer-group. This command also can tag a peer-group as internal (iBGP) or external (eBGP)

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# peer-group PG_Ext sonic(config-router-bgp-pg)# remote-as 65200

COMMAND.name: timers

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command enables user to configure keepalive, hold and connect timer intervals for a BGP peer-group.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to configure keeplaive, hold and connect retry timer intervals for a BGP peer-group.

EXAMPLE.summary: Following command configures keepalive and hold timer interval for peer-group PG_Ext to 3 and 9 seconds respectively

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# peer-group PG_Ext sonic(config-router-bgp-pg)# timers 3 9

DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to administratively shutdown a BGP peer-group sessions

COMMAND.name: capability extended-nexthop
COMMAND.help: Advertise extended next-hop capability to the peer

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command allows bgp to negotiate the extended-nexthop capability with it's peer in a peer-group. If you are peering over a v6 LL address then this capability is turned on automatically. If you are peering over a v6 Global Address then turning on this command will allow BGP to install v4 routes with v6 nexthops if you do not have v4 configured on interfaces.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to turn on extended-nexthop capability for a BGP peer-group

EXAMPLE.summary: Following command enables extended-nexthop capability for BGP peer-group PG_Ext

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# peer-group PG_Ext sonic(config-router-bgp-pg)# capability extended-nexthop

COMMAND.name: capability dynamic
COMMAND.help: Advertise dynamic capability to this neighbor

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command allows bgp to advertise dynamic capability to neighbors in a peer-group
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to turn on dynamic capability for a BGP peer-group

EXAMPLE.summary: Following command enables dynamic capability for BGP peer-group PG_Ext

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# peer-group PG_Ext sonic(config-router-bgp-pg)# capability dynamic

COMMAND.name: disable-connected-check
COMMAND.help: One-hop away EBGP peer using loopback address

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command disables the restriction that eBGP peers must be directly connected
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to allow peerings between directly connected eBGP peers using loopback addresses.

EXAMPLE.summary: Following command disables connected check for BGP peer-group PG_Ext

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# peer-group PG_Ext sonic(config-router-bgp-pg)# disable-connected-check

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION:
This command suppresses sending Capability Negotiation as OPEN message optional parameter to neighbors in a peer-group. This command only affects the peer is configured other than IPv4 unicast configuration.
When remote peer does not have capability negotiation feature, remote peer will not send any capabilities at all. In that case, bgp configures the peer with configured capabilities.
You may prefer locally configured capabilities more than the negotiated capabilities even though remote peer sends capabilities. If the peer is configured by override-capability, BGP ignores received capabilities then override negotiated capabilities with configured values.
Additionally the user should be reminded that this feature fundamentally disables the ability to use widely deployed BGP features - BGP unnumbered, hostname support, AS4, Addpath, Route Refresh, ORF, Dynamic Capabilities, and graceful restart.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to disable capability negotiation for BGP neighbors in a peer-group

EXAMPLE.summary: Following command disables capability negotiation for BGP peer-group PG_Ext

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# peer-group PG_Ext sonic(config-router-bgp-pg)# dont-capability-negotiate

COMMAND.name: enforce-first-as
COMMAND.help: Enforce the first AS for EBGP routes

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command enforces that first AS in as-path of a route received from BGP peer must be peer's AS number
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to enforce that first AS in as-path of route from eBGP peer must be peer's local AS number

EXAMPLE.summary: Following command enables enforcement of first AS number for BGP peer-group PG_Ext

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# peer-group PG_Ext sonic(config-router-bgp-pg)# enforce-first-as

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command enforces that eBGP neighbors in a peer-group perform multihop
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to enforce eBGP neighbors in a peer-group perform multihop

EXAMPLE.summary: Following command enables enforce-multihop for BGP peer-group PG_Ext

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# peer-group PG_Ext sonic(config-router-bgp-pg)# enforce-multihop

COMMAND.name: local-as

PARAM.name: no-prepend
PARAM.help: Do not prepend local-as to updates from ebgp peers

PARAM.name: replace-as
PARAM.help: Do not prepend local-as to updates from ibgp peers

COMMAND.ACTION:
if test -n "${no-prepend}" ; then
python $SONIC_CLI_ROOT/sonic_cli_bgp.py patch_openconfig_bgp_ext_network_instances_network_instance_protocols_protocol_bgp_peer_groups_peer_group_config_local_as_no_prepend ${vrf-name} ${template-name} True
else
python $SONIC_CLI_ROOT/sonic_cli_bgp.py patch_openconfig_bgp_ext_network_instances_network_instance_protocols_protocol_bgp_peer_groups_peer_group_config_local_as_no_prepend ${vrf-name} ${template-name} False
fi
if test -n "${replace-as}" ; then
python $SONIC_CLI_ROOT/sonic_cli_bgp.py patch_openconfig_bgp_ext_network_instances_network_instance_protocols_protocol_bgp_peer_groups_peer_group_config_local_as_replace_as ${vrf-name} ${template-name} True
else
python $SONIC_CLI_ROOT/sonic_cli_bgp.py patch_openconfig_bgp_ext_network_instances_network_instance_protocols_protocol_bgp_peer_groups_peer_group_config_local_as_replace_as ${vrf-name} ${template-name} False
fi
python $SONIC_CLI_ROOT/sonic_cli_bgp.py patch_openconfig_network_instance_network_instances_network_instance_protocols_protocol_bgp_peer_groups_peer_group_config_local_as ${vrf-name} ${template-name} ${asnum}

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION:
This command specifies an alternate AS for this BGP process when interacting with the specified peers in a peer-group. With no modifiers, the specified local-as is prepended to the received AS_PATH when receiving routing updates from the peer, and prepended to the outgoing AS_PATH (after the process local AS) when transmitting local routes to the peer.
If the no-prepend CLI option is specified, then the supplied local-as is not prepended to the received AS_PATH.
If the replace-as CLI option is specified, then only the supplied local-as is prepended to the AS_PATH when transmitting local-route updates to this peer.
Note that replace-as can only be specified if no-prepend is.
This command is only allowed for eBGP peers.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to configure local AS number for BGP neighbors in a peer-group and control how the local AS number is prepended to the AS_PATH of incoming and outgoing routes.

EXAMPLE.summary: Following command configures local AS and enables no-prepend for BGP peer-group PG_Ext

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# peer-group PG_Ext sonic(config-router-bgp-pg)# local-as 65200 non-prepend

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command instructs BGP to override the result of Capability Negotiation with local configuration. Ignore remote peer's capability value.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to ignored the negotiated capability parameters with neighbors in a peer-group and instead use the locally configured parameters.

EXAMPLE.summary: Following command instructs BGP to ignore the negotiated parameters and use the locally configured one for neighbors in peer-group PG_Ext

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# peer-group PG_Ext sonic(config-router-bgp-pg)# override-capability

COMMAND.name: passive
COMMAND.help: Don't send open messages to this neighbor

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command makes BGP neighbors in a peer-group passive. That is, BGP neighbors will not initiate a session. However, it will listen to any incoming BGP session.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to set BGP neighbors in a peer-group as passive.

EXAMPLE.summary: Following command makes BGP neighbors in peer-group PG_Ext passive

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# peer-group PG_Ext sonic(config-router-bgp-pg)# passive

PARAM.name: encrypted
PARAM.help: The password is stored in an encrypted format

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command sets a MD5 password to be used with the tcp socket that is being used to connect to the remote peers in a peer-group.
DOCGEN.USAGE: This command is for security purposes. When Password is configures for BGP neighbors in a peer-group, sender will include a 16-bytes MD5 digest in TCP header of BGP message and the receiver should be able to validate the digest then only accept the BGP message.

EXAMPLE.summary: Following command configures password for BGP neighbors in a peer-group PG_Ext

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# peer-group PG_Ext sonic(config-router-bgp-pg)# password ilovebeansbecausetheyaremean

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command sets TCP port for BGP neighbors in a peer-group.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to set a specific port for BGP neighbors in a peer-group. This command is optional.

EXAMPLE.summary: Following command configures TCP port for BGP peer-group PG_Ext

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# peer-group PG_Ext sonic(config-router-bgp-pg)# port 65001

COMMAND.name: solo
COMMAND.help: Solo peer - part of its own update group

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command is used to indicate that routes advertised by the peer should not be reflected back to the peer. This command is only meaningful when there is a single peer defined in the peer-group.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to set a peer-group solo

EXAMPLE.summary: Following command configures BGP peer-group PG_Ext as solo

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# peer-group PG_Ext sonic(config-router-bgp-pg)# solo

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command instructs BGP to strictly compare remote capabilities and local capabilities. If capabilities are different, send Unsupported Capability error then reset connection.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command for a BGP peer-group to enforce exact matching of sent and received capabilities

EXAMPLE.summary: Following command enables strict capability match for BGP peer-group PG_Ext

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# peer-group PG_Ext sonic(config-router-bgp-pg)# strict-capability-match

PARAM.name: nhops
PARAM.help: Specify the maximum number of hops to the BGP peer

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command enforces Generalized TTL Security Mechanism (GTSM), as specified in RFC 5082. With this command, only neighbors that are the specified number of hops away will be allowed to become neighbors. This command is mutually exclusive with ebgp-multihop.
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command for a BGP peer-group to enable Generalized TTL Security Mechanism (GTSM). This is for security purposes.

EXAMPLE.summary: Following command enables GTSM for BGP peer-group PG_Ext

DOCGEN.EXAMPLE: sonic# configure terminal sonic(config)# router bgp 100 sonic(config-router-bgp)# peer-group PG_Ext sonic(config-router-bgp-pg)# ttl-security hops 8

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command switches the CLI context into IPv4 Unicast address-family mode for a BGP peer-group
DOCGEN.USAGE: Use this command to switch to IPv4 Unicast address family CLI context of a BGP peer-group to configure parameters specific to this address family

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command switches the CLI context into IPv6 Unicast address-family mode for a BGP peer-group

DOCGEN.DESCRIPTION: This command switches the CLI context into L2VPN EVPN address-family mode for a BGP peer-group
